NodeComment:
This module implements a formal system named "Propositional Logic" which is the most well known logical system.

Logic, in general, works so well with traditional derivation system, hence there is spacial name called "Natural Deduction" which is a combination of any kind of Logic together with derivation system.

For further information, please see chapter 5 (Example Formal System - Propositional Logic) in Phometa documentation.
This example only holds only under Classical Logic.

The rules so far create Intuitionistic Logic. It doesn't assume that each proposition must be either true or false. Hence, cannot prove some thing like (A ∨ (¬ A)).

We could add "law of exclude middle" or "double negation" axiom to make Intuitionistic Logic becomes classical logic. Alternatively, we can introduce "proof by contradiction" rule to make it become classical logic as well. And now we can prove "law of exclude middle" and "double negation" as lemmas below.

Although we prove validity of "Judgement" to show that curtain proposition holds under curtain assumptions. But "Prop" it self has meaning of validity as well, that is, such a proposition holds without any assumptions. Hence, we could let introduce a rule to prove sole "Prop" like this.

Context in Propositional Logic is just a set of assumption so the order and duplication among assumptions shouldn't matter. The three rules below allow context to be manipulated during proving a theorem.
Here are examples of some theorems that have been proven.
Here are primitive rules that can be used to prove judgements. Each connector usually have rules regarding to introduction and elimination as you can see below.
"hypothesis-base" is just a helper rule for "hypothesis" and shouldn't be used to prove a theorem directly.
Propositional Logic has 4 grammars which are "Prop", "Atom", "Context", and "Judgement" described below.

This module implements a formal system named "Simple Arithmetic". It aims to be the first example of formal system for new comer to play around. Please note that this is just a faction of actual arithmetic modified to make it easy to understand, so it is not as powerful as the actual one.

For further information, please see chapter 3 (Background) and chapter 4 (Example Formal System - Simple Arithmetic) in Phometa documentation.
2 example below shows how theorem should look like.

"dist-right" is suppose to be an axiom similar to dist-left. However, it can be derived from existing rules and axioms above. So I prove it and lock it as lemma for further use. In this way, user can see how to use lemma as well.
Simple Arithmetic has several rules explained below. Please note that these are not exhaustive, it only aims to explain basic feature of phometa.
Simple Arithmetic has 4 grammars which are "Digit", "Number", "Expr", and "Equation" described below.
